Diagonalizing $A$ is also like moving $A$ into a basis where it is diagonal:
$PAP^{-1} = D$

$\sin (A) = P (\Lambda - \frac{\Lambda^3}{3!} + \frac{\Lambda^5}{5!} - \dots)P^{-1}$
$\sin (A) = P \sin(\Lambda) P^{-1}$ (holds for all power series)

$(e^{At})' = Ae^{At}$ by the power series definition, so the solution to $Y' = AY$ is $Y = e^{At}Y_0$
$e^{At} = P e^{\Lambda t} P^{-1}$

In the complex plane:
$P = \matrixstart u \pm iv \matrixend$
$\Lambda = diag(a \pm ib)$

So $e^{At}$ is the same as before. But we can keep things in the real plane with a trick.
We know that the entire thing must be real when you finish the multiplications, but that's a lot of computation.

We let $P = \matrixstart u & v \matrixend, D = \matrixstart a & b \\ -b & a \matrixend$
Then $A = PDP^{-1}$

Because $e^{(a + ib)t} = e^{at}(\cos(bt) + i\sin(bt)$,
$e^{At} = e^{at} P R(bt) P^{-1}$
